summary: Russia carried out one of its most significant missile attacks on Kyiv, Ukraine's capital, since the invasion began in 2022. This escalation marks a notable increase in hostilities in the region.

title: Pakistan suspends visas for Indians after deadly Kashmir attack on tourists
snippets: It comes after Delhi's retaliatory measures following a militant attack in Indian-administered Kashmir that killed 26 tourists.
titles: Pakistan suspends visas for Indians after deadly Kashmir attack on tourists
summary: Following a militant attack in Indian-administered Kashmir that resulted in the deaths of 26 tourists, the government of Delhi has implemented retaliatory measures. These actions were taken in response to the violent incident, aiming to address the security concerns raised by the attack.

snippets: Kyiv struck with missiles and drones overnight; rescue operations continue amid widespread destruction and casualties.
titles: Russia unleashes deadliest Kyiv air attack this year
summary: Kyiv was hit by missiles and drones in an overnight attack, leading to widespread destruction and casualties. Rescue operations are currently ongoing to address the aftermath of the incident.

title: Bad Boys and 'Detroit energy': What's behind this record-setting turnaround for the Pistons
snippets: The Pistons finished with one of the worst records in NBA history last season. Now, they enter Thursday's Game 3 tied 1-1 with the Knicks. What changed in Detroit?
titles: Bad Boys and 'Detroit energy': What's behind this record-setting turnaround for the Pistons
summary: The Detroit Pistons, after finishing last season with one of the NBA's worst records, have shown significant improvement. As they head into Game 3 against the New York Knicks, the series is tied at 1-1, indicating a notable turnaround in their performance compared to the previous season.

titles: Indy 500 open test red flagged again due to Takuma Sato wreck
summary: During the two-day practice sessions for the Indianapolis 500, known as "The Greatest Spectacle in Racing," a two-time winner of the event crashed minutes after Kyle Larson did in the first incident. Both incidents occurred while preparing for the upcoming race.

title: Corporate America puts Wall Street on alert over damage from trade war
snippets: Executives use earnings calls to lay out impact of Trump’s tariffs on costs and supply chains
titles: Corporate America puts Wall Street on alert over damage from trade war
summary: During earnings calls, executives have detailed the effects of President Trump's tariffs on their companies' costs and supply chains. They have discussed how these tariffs are influencing their business operations, including increased expenses and disruptions in the flow of goods. This information helps stakeholders understand the financial and logistical challenges these companies face due to the tariffs.

title: Trump urges Putin to stop attacks on Ukraine
snippets: US president signals frustration with Kremlin even as his administration makes overtures towards Russia
titles: Trump urges Putin to stop attacks on Ukraine
summary: The US President has shown signs of frustration with the Kremlin, despite his administration actively seeking to engage with Russia. This indicates a complex diplomatic relationship where, on one hand, the US is attempting to establish communication and possibly cooperation with Russia, while on the other, there are underlying tensions and dissatisfaction expressed by the President.

titles: Ukraine fails to reach deal with investors to restructure $2.6bn of debt
summary: Kyiv is scheduled to make an estimated payment of $600 million on GDP warrants next month. This financial obligation is part of the country's economic commitments.

title: Keurig Dr Pepper Soft Drink Sales Take Off, But Coffee Costs Limit Gains
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Keurig Dr Pepper beat profit and sales estimates as demand for its U.S. soft drinks jumped.
  • U.S. coffee revenue slid, hurt by "escalating green coffee costs."
  • The company added two new independent board members, and Executive Chair Bob Gamgort has moved to Non-Executive Chair.


Shares of Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP) fell slightly Thursday morning even as the coffee and soft drink maker posted better-than-expected results, lifted by U.S. beverage sales. However, the impact of soaring coffee prices muted investor enthusiasm.

The company reported first-quarter adjusted earnings per share (EPS) of $0.42, with revenue rising 5% year-over-year to $3.64 billion. Both exceeded Visible Alpha estimates.

U.S. Refreshment Beverages unit sales were 11% higher at $2.3 billion, boosted by "volume/mix growth of 8% and favorable net price realization of 3%." However, U.S. coffee sales slumped nearly 4% to $900 million, hurt by a volume/mix decline that included "pricing actions implemented in reaction to escalating green coffee costs." International sales dropped 6% to $400 million.

Keurig Dr Pepper affirmed its full-year guidance of adjusted EPS increasing by a high-single-digit percentage, and constant-currency sales up by a mid-single-digit percentage. 

In addition, the company announced that it added Mike Van de Ven and Lawson Whiting as independent directors, and that Executive Chair Bob Gamgort has shifted to Non-Executive Chair. 

Keurig Dr Pepper shares slipped less than 1% Thursday morning but have gained about 9% in 2025.
titles: Keurig Dr Pepper Soft Drink Sales Take Off, But Coffee Costs Limit Gains
summary: Keurig Dr Pepper reported better-than-expected first-quarter results, with a 5% increase in revenue to $3.64 billion and an EPS of $0.42, surpassing estimates. U.S. soft drink sales rose by 11% to $2.3 billion, while U.S. coffee sales dropped nearly 4% to $900 million due to high green coffee costs. International sales fell by 6%. Despite these results, shares fell slightly. The company confirmed its full-year earnings and sales growth guidance and announced the addition of two new independent board members, with Bob Gamgort moving to Non-Executive Chair.

title: Union Pacific Results Come Up Short as Railroad Faced 'Uncertain Environment'
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Union Pacific said it faced an uncertain economic environment, and earnings and revenue missed forecasts.
  • The freight train giant saw energy and automotive shipment sales slide.
  • Union Pacific shares fell 4% Thursday morning.


Union Pacific (UNP) shares dropped Thursday as the big freight railroad operator missed quarterly profit and sales forecasts on slumping energy and automotive shipments and lower fuel surcharges.

The company reported first-quarter earnings per share (EPS) of $2.70 on essentially flat operating revenue of $6.03 billion. Analysts surveyed by Visible Alpha were looking for $2.75 and $6.07 billion, respectively.

The carrier's 7% increase in volume and higher prices were offset by "business mix, reduced fuel surcharge revenue, lower other revenue, and impact from leap year." Energy and specialized market freight revenue tumbled 7% to $633 million, automotive freight sales slid 5% to $581 million, and food and refrigerated shipment revenue was down 9% to $260 million.

CEO Jim Vena said Union Pacific "worked closely with our customers to meet their needs in an uncertain environment."

Including today's 4% declines, shares of Union Pacific have lost about 7.5% this year.
titles: Union Pacific Results Come Up Short as Railroad Faced 'Uncertain Environment'
summary: Union Pacific reported a decline in quarterly profit and sales, missing analysts' forecasts due to a drop in energy and automotive shipments and lower fuel surcharges. Earnings per share were $2.70, below the expected $2.75, with operating revenue at $6.03 billion, missing the forecast of $6.07 billion. The decrease in revenue from energy and specialized market freight, automotive freight, and food and refrigerated shipments contributed to the shortfall. Following the report, Union Pacific shares fell by 4%, contributing to a total loss of about 7.5% for the year. CEO Jim Vena highlighted effo

title: Colossal ancient icebergs left grooves on the bottom of the North Sea
snippets: Scientists have found scour marks on the seabed made by giant icebergs about 18,000 years ago, and they could offer clues to the fate of Antarctica’s ice
titles: Colossal ancient icebergs left grooves on the bottom of the North Sea
summary: Scientists discovered scour marks on the seabed created by giant icebergs around 18,000 years ago. These marks may provide insights into the future of Antarctica's ice.

title: The supplement that really can improve your brain health
snippets: Most supplements that claim to help your brain have never been thoroughly tested, but one has convinced even the most discerning scientists of its worth, finds columnist Helen Thomson
titles: The supplement that really can improve your brain health
summary: Most brain health supplements lack thorough testing, yet one has gained credibility among discerning scientists, according to columnist Helen Thomson.

title: Daily doses of peanuts could desensitise adults with the allergy
snippets: Exposing children with peanut allergy to proteins from the legume is an approved treatment to reduce the risk of allergic reactions, and now we have evidence it also works in adults
titles: Daily doses of peanuts could desensitise adults with the allergy
summary: A treatment that involves exposing individuals with peanut allergies to small amounts of peanut protein, previously proven effective for children, has now been shown to also reduce the risk of allergic reactions in adults. This approach aims to increase tolerance to peanut exposure.

title: First evidence of gladiator fight with lion seen in Roman-era skeleton
snippets: A man who lived in Roman-occupied Britain was bitten by a big cat, probably in a gladiator arena, an analysis of his remains has revealed
titles: First evidence of gladiator fight with lion seen in Roman-era skeleton
summary: An analysis of remains has shown that a man from Roman-occupied Britain was likely bitten by a big cat, possibly in a gladiator arena. This conclusion is based on the examination of the injuries found on his body.

title: Can climate science attribute economic damage to major polluters?
snippets: Climate researchers argue their science has advanced enough to directly link emissions from particular companies to damages from specific extreme weather events
titles: Can climate science attribute economic damage to major polluters?
summary: Climate researchers have made advancements in their field, enabling them to directly connect emissions from specific companies to damages caused by particular extreme weather events. This development marks a significant step in the ability to attribute responsibility for climate-related damages.
